commentary_central: Higher inflation data continues into February and is compounded by policy actions that lead the Fed to hold rates again
commentary_higher: Inflationary resurgence leads the Fed to reverse course and raise rates
commentary_lower: Further inflationary progress towards target and/or still cooling labour market means the Fed continues removing restrictiveness

commentary_central: Disinflationary pressures remain elusive in the first quarter of the year and the Fed wants confirmation of inflation moving back to target before it cuts and continues to hold
commentary_higher: Inflationary trends are judged to be more than seasonal or just one off hits from tariffs and the Fed raises rates in response
commentary_lower: Consumer confidence or business sentiment weaken dramatically and begin to spill over into the labour market and prompt the Fed to move faster, downplaying inflation concerns

commentary_central: The Fed cuts once as broad disinflation continues and activity and labour market indicators continue to trend lower
commentary_higher: Inflationary policies from a new US administration and a lack of meaningful additional progress force the Fed to move at a slow pace and keep rates higher for longer
commentary_lower: The Fed has to deliver more cuts owing to a sharp deterioration in the real economy including declines in consumption and business investment as sentiment declines

commentary_central: The Fed continues very gradual policy normalisation as new policies do not fully offset the broader disinflationary trend
commentary_higher: Expansionary policies from a new US administration and a lack of meaningful additional progress on inflation force the Fed to keep rates higher for longer
commentary_lower: The Fed has to deliver more cuts owing to weakness in the real economy

commentary_central: The Fed continues gradual path of easing towards neutral
commentary_higher: Inflationary policies require interest rates to stay higher or rise
commentary_lower: Weakness in real economy leads to faster pace of cuts

commentary_central: The Fed continues gradual path of easing towards neutral
commentary_higher: Inflationary policies require interest rates to stay higher or rise
commentary_lower: Weakness in real economy leads to faster pace of cuts

commentary_central: Interest rates converge on a rate similar to the long-term trend growth of the US economy plus inflation, although the path towards these rates might be bumpy with long periods outside the range.
commentary_higher: Strong growth or a growing lack of confidence in US public finances requires a higher neutral interest rate.
commentary_lower: Weak and persistently low growth generates few outside options for savings, helping the longer-term interest rate to fall to low levels.

commentary_central: Disinflation continues and the pick-up in activity is mild, prompting the ECB to continue with a gradual pace of easing.
commentary_higher: The consumer recovery is stronger than expected and Trump’s early policy signals milder, convincing the ECB to keep a restrictive stance
commentary_lower: Trump’s policy agenda turns out to be more aggressive than expected, or private consumption fails to pick up as hoped, prompting the ECB to cut faster.

commentary_central: Disinflation continues and the pick-up in activity is mild, prompting the ECB to continue with a gradual pace of easing.
commentary_higher: The consumer recovery is stronger than expected and Trump’s early policy signals milder, convincing the ECB to keep a restrictive stance
commentary_lower: Trump’s policy agenda turns out to be more aggressive than expected, or private consumption fails to pick up as hoped, prompting the ECB to cut faster.

commentary_central: Disinflation continues on track and growth continues to disappoint in the first half. The ECB responds by cutting rates for the third time in 2025 in June.
commentary_higher: The consumer recovery emerges stronger than expected, reigniting fears of inflation and prompting the ECB to proceed more cautiously.
commentary_lower: Signs of a consumer-led recovery fail to emerge and growth indicators continue to tick down, concerns about labour market strength have risen. The ECB delivers its fourth quarter-point cut for the year in June and the debate about additional easing to promote growth begins.

commentary_central: The ECB cuts rates four to five times, taking the benchmark at or just below neutral as the European economy slows down.
commentary_higher: Growth and consumption both respond well to lower rates and the ECB fears resurgent inflation and fails to take rates to their neutral levels by the end of the year.
commentary_lower: Consumer weakness becomes apparent and fears of undershooting become the primary driver of policy. Rates fall below neutral.

commentary_central: The ECB delivers another rate cut after December 2025, keeping the stance slightly accommodative
commentary_higher: The ECB keeps rates close to neutral as a strong pick-up in consumption keeps inflation at target
commentary_lower: The ECB delivers additional rate cuts after persistently weak consumption and an unfavourable international environment raise the risks of undershooting.

commentary_central: The ECB delivers another rate cut after December 2025, keeping the stance slightly accommodative
commentary_higher: The ECB keeps rates close to neutral as a strong pick-up in consumption keeps inflation at target
commentary_lower: The ECB delivers additional rate cuts after persistently weak consumption and an unfavourable international environment raise the risks of undershooting.

commentary_central: Interest rates converge on a rate similar to the expected inflation rate and lower than nominal GDP.
commentary_higher: More potential investment opportunity or an uplift in productivity would require a higher neutral interest rate.
commentary_lower: Weak potential output and persistently low investment generate few outside options for savings, helping the long-term interest rate to fall to low levels.

commentary_central: We expect the BoE to hold in March, maintaining the gradual pace of monetary easing since August.
commentary_higher: MPC decide to leave rates unchanged, noting greater inflationary pressures from October’s Budget than they had at first expected
commentary_lower: UK activity and inflation slows significantly in the first months of 2025, leading to fears of stagnation and a rapid drop in inflation without a more aggressive programme of cuts

commentary_central: We expect the BoE to hold in March, maintaining the gradual pace of monetary easing since August.
commentary_higher: MPC decide to leave rates unchanged, noting greater inflationary pressures from October’s Budget than they had at first expected
commentary_lower: UK activity and inflation slows significantly in the first months of 2025, leading to fears of stagnation and a rapid drop in inflation without a more aggressive programme of cuts

commentary_central: The UK economy continues to disinflate gradually, allowing two quarter point rate cuts by summer 2025. Fears of inflation persistence beginning to subside
commentary_higher: MPC decides to slow rate cuts in 2025 on evidence that inflation pass through has been higher than hoped, raising the unpleasant prospect of continued persistence in too rapid price and wage rises
commentary_lower: UK activity and inflation stagnates in 2025, requiring the MPC to bring rates quickly out of a restrictive position, seeking to boost economic activity

commentary_central: The BoE will deliver five cuts in 2025 as it eases policy towards a more neutral rate.
commentary_higher: Concerns about remaining inflationary pressure leaves the MPC reluctant to significantly relax its stance.
commentary_lower: The UK economy weakens significantly, requiring the BoE to stimulate demand.

commentary_central: The BoE delivers two more cuts by mid-2026 as interest rates converge towards neutral levels.
commentary_higher: Ongoing strong wage demands and the resulting higher inflation mean fewer rate cuts from the MPC
commentary_lower: A weak economic outlook sees the MPC cut rates close to, or even below, the neutral rate.

commentary_central: The BoE continues to gradually ease rates by end 2026, converging towards neutral levels.
commentary_higher: Ongoing strong wage demands and the resulting higher inflation mean fewer rate cuts from the MPC
commentary_lower: A weak economic outlook sees the MPC cut rates close to, or even below, the neutral rate.

commentary_central: Interest rates converge on a rate similar to the expected inflation rate and lower than nominal GDP, due to stronger public finances and lower potential growth rates. The path towards these rates might be bumpy with long periods outside the range. Hence the low probability for a central scenario.
commentary_higher: Stronger growth or a growing lack of confidence in UK public finances would require a higher neutral interest rate. Strong growth because plentiful potential alternative investments allow savers to demand higher returns and weak public finances because government needs to attract more savings.
commentary_lower: Weak growth and persistently low investment generates few outside options for savings, helping the longer-term interest rate to fall to low levels.

commentary_central: The BoJ continues to wait for more evidence of Trump’s impact and avoids being forced to tighten by yen weakness
commentary_higher: BoJ imposes back-to-back rate rises after serious dislocation in currency markets requires tighter monetary policy to restore stability
commentary_lower: The BoJ lowers rates to respond to sudden economic threats

commentary_central: The BoJ holds again in May and slowly gathers evidence for the timing of its next move higher
commentary_higher: Rapid wage growth in the spring wage round and sharp yen weakening prompts the BoJ to opt for another rate increase
commentary_lower: The BoJ responds to a difficult global environment in the first few months of a Trump US presidency, reversing its January rate hike

commentary_central: The BoJ assesses that wage growth inflation trends are on track following spring wage negotiations but makes another step towards neutral rates
commentary_higher: Wage trends and inflation exceed the BoJ’s expectations, forcing it set a faster path of normalisation
commentary_lower: The BoJ hold rates with a view to raising them again later in the summer

commentary_central: The BoJ assesses that wage growth and inflation trends are still on track and maintains rates with a view to an early rate rise at the start of 2026
commentary_higher: Wage indications at the end of 2025 are sufficiently strong for the BoJ to take another step towards neutral rates, achieving that goal this year
commentary_lower: The BoJ continues to hold rates in response to weaker wage and inflation developments or increased risks from an external shocks

commentary_central: The BoJ assesses that wage growth inflation trends are on track following spring wage negotiations and continues to push rates slowly higher
commentary_higher: The BoJ becomes confident that wages and prices will reinforce one another and seeks a faster path towards neutral rates
commentary_lower: The BoJ holds rates in response to weaker wage and inflation developments or increased risks from an external shock such as trade tariffs

commentary_central: The BoJ assesses that wage growth inflation trends are on track and achieves the mid point of our neutral rates range
commentary_higher: The BoJ becomes confident that wages and prices will reinforce one another and seeks a more normal range for interest rates
commentary_lower: The BoJ holds rates lower in response to weaker wage and inflation developments or increased risks from an external shock such as trade tariffs

commentary_central: Interest rates converge on a relatively low neutral rate.
commentary_higher: A successful emergence from decades of weak growth and inflation would require higher neutral interest rates.
commentary_lower: Japan falls back into its low inflation trap, failing to generate domestic inflation and wage growth.
